12.text:
Famously never said: “Attitude Is A Little
Thing That makes A Big Difference,” “If

16.text:
you’re not a liberal when you’re 25, you
have no heart. If you’re not a conservative

19.text: by the time you’re 35, you have no brain.”

23.text:
Aside from Neo-Nazis, who doesn’t love Winston
Churchill? He led England to victory in World

27.text:
War II, helped his country recover from the
conflict, and told an ugly woman to her face

31.text:
that she was ugly and would wake up ugly the
next morning as well…we think.

35.text:
He apparently spoke in nothing but quotable
platitudes, unable to even ask where the bathroom

40.text:
was without inspiring everyone around him
to become better human beings and to always

45.text:
fight, never surrender, blah blah blah. This
can’t possibly be true, since the man was

50.text:
a raging drunk half the day who spent the
other half eating. The man loved putting things

55.text: into his mouth, is what we’re saying.

57.text:
Now unless your father ran it before you,
you obviously can’t run a country without

61.text:
being at least a tad intelligent. And he truly
WAS a well-spoken, highly quotable man. But

67.text:
not to the extent people think; let’s give
Churchill a break and stop pretending every

71.text:
movie-worthy quote about war and life originated
from his lips.

77.text:
Famously never said: “We’ve cleaned up
the air, but polluted the soul,” “I like

82.text:
big cars, big cigars, and naturally big racks,”
anything else your Inbox says he said.

88.text:
Good ol’ angry opinionated George. He never
had any issue with speaking his mind, and

91.text:
virtually everybody respected him for that.
So, when some random nobody wants to make

96.text:
a point, stick ol’ George’s name on it
and people will listen!

100.text:
Problem: a good chunk of these misattributed
essays, quotes, and stories didn’t even

104.text:
come close to what Carlin truly thought. Racism,
homophobia, jingoism, and not being funny

110.text:
in the least; none of these positions Carlin
endorsed, and yet all appear in these anonymous

115.text:
essays credited to him. It actually embarrassed
him, and when the guy who proposed that Colorado

121.text:
be fenced in and that chronic drug addicts
and alcoholics should be sent there gets embarrassed,

128.text:
Luckily, Georgie offered a very easy way to
determine if that blurb in your inbox is his:

133.text:
“Nothing you see on the Internet is mine
unless it comes from one of my albums, books,

138.text:
HBO specials, or appeared on my website.”
Has this stopped people from forwarding “George

143.text:
Carlin’s” insightful essay on why he likes
big cars, big boats, and big tits? Of course

152.text:
Famously never sang: “Windows 95 Sucks,”
“What If God Smoked Cannabis,” “Dirty

159.text:
Whenever somebody has a “funny” song that
can’t get promoted because it’s actually

162.text:
not funny in the least, they just stick Weird
Al’s name on it and sit back as tons of

166.text:
suckers download a track that’s actually
more tragedy than comedy.

171.text:
Why do they do this? Because Al’s incredibly
popular and, for many people, he’s the only

175.text:
guy ever to parody other people’s music.
The problem here is that they attribute songs

180.text:
to him that are distinctly R-rated, and sometimes
racist or sexist, while Al is very much family-oriented

187.text:
(that one song about Santa Claus murdering
everybody notwithstanding).

191.text:
How can you tell if “Walk With An Erection”
is an Al song or not? Simple; is it on an

195.text:
Al CD? Or mentioned on his web site? No? Then
it’s not his. Gee, that was easy.

203.text:
Famously never said: “Good works are links
that form a chain of love,” “I know God

208.text:
will not give me anything I can’t handle.
I just wish that He didn’t trust me so much.”

213.text:
If you have something you want people to take
seriously, just precede it with the phrase

218.text:
“like Mother Theresa once said…” Because
who doesn’t love Mother Theresa? Even the

222.text:
most non-religious of people would concede
that, by and large, she was pretty cool with

226.text:
the whole vow of poverty and devoting her
life to the poorest of the poor thing.

230.text:
The best part of everybody loving her is,
who’s gonna call you out if you misattribute

234.text:
some random BS quote to her? Who are you to
doubt the (then) Living Saint? As a result,

239.text:
an ever-growing number of quotes and lines
are floating around, very few of which were

244.text:
ever uttered by her. She was too busy aiding
the sick and hungry to work on her sound bites,

251.text:
Famously never said: “The Constitution only
gives people the right to pursue happiness.

256.text:
You have to catch it yourself,” “Beer
is proof God loves us and wants us to be happy.”

262.text:
Ben Franklin, much like Thomas Jefferson and
Abraham Lincoln, gets quotes attached to him

266.text:
all the damn time, for two reasons. One, he
was incredibly smart and respected, and continues

271.text:
to be so to this day. Also, he’s dead. So
he can’t exactly go on Conan tonight and

277.text:
tell the masses that he never said God made
beer because he loves us. Besides, if that

283.text:
Tons upon tons upon tons of lines are slapped
with Franklin’s name. Many of these are

288.text:
either mangled versions of something far less
profound that he actually said, things said

293.text:
by politicians much less interesting than
the $100 bill guy, or just something completely

298.text:
made up by AwEsumDoode420187, who at least
realized nobody cared what he had to say because

303.text: he is, in fact, not very awesome at all.

308.text:
Famously never said: “A home opener is always
exciting, no matter if it’s home or on the

314.text:
road.,” “I can’t concentrate when I’m
thinking.,” “I usually take a two hour

320.text:
Yogi was famous for saying things that made
absolutely no sense. But, because he was an

324.text:
amazing baseball player, he got away with
it. This is the guy who said “it ain’t

328.text:
over till it’s over” which contradicts
itself so much it actually un-contradicts

332.text:
itself and makes perfect sense the more you
think about it. If any of us said that, we’d

337.text:
be committed immediately. But when he does
it, it’s a charming “Yogi-ism.”

340.text:
But wait, did he even say that? Nobody seems
to know. So many of these goofy lines are

346.text:
attributed to Berra, but are typically un-sourced
otherwise. No dates, no places, no footage

351.text:
of him flapping his gums and actually saying
“I’d give my right arm to be ambidextrous”.

356.text:
Just somebody who wrote something silly down
and stuck Yogi’s name on it. Because then

363.text:
Yogi himself doesn’t seem interested in
setting the record straight, unlike some other

367.text:
figures listed here. And why would he? It’s
his legend, for better or for worse. Best

371.text: to run with it as long as possible.

376.text:
Famously never said: “Time you enjoy wasting
is not wasted time,” that really long quote

379.text:
no problem writing this really long run-on
sentence in its place which kinda negates

380.text:
Lennon is like Mother Theresa in that you
can put his head next to just about any pseudo-inspirational

385.text:
quote and it immediately gains street cred,
because it’s John Lennon and he wrote”

390.text:
Imagine”, and he obviously knows how life
works. So he MUST’VE said that awesome bit

394.text:
you stuck on your Facebook page about how
any time you enjoy wasting is not wasted time.

399.text:
Well, no, he didn’t say that. He also didn’t
say that his teachers didn’t understand

403.text:
life, and when he sang about life happening
while you make other plans, he was aping that

408.text:
line from somebody else. Suddenly, John Lennon
isn’t the all-knowing guru he’s hyped

412.text:
up to be. But he DID sing “Imagine,” so
you’re right about that one at least.

419.text:
Famously never said: “As of 1992, they’ll
be called European Economic Community fries,”

424.text:
“What are imitation rhinestones?” “If
God dropped acid, would he see people?”

429.text:
Steven’s stand-up is based on absurd and
incredibly surreal one-liners such as, “one

434.text:
day I was walking alone in the forest, and
a tree fell right in front me me…and I didn’t

439.text:
hear it.” Occasionally, he plays guitar
and teases performing songs titled, “They’ll

443.text:
find her when the leaves blow away, cuz I’m
not raking ‘till Spring.” He’s an odd

450.text:
Even though he tells said jokes in an incredibly
droll monotone, he can still fit a couple

454.text:
hundred of them into one performance. This
makes attributing random, much less funny

458.text:
quotes to him incredibly easy. After all,
many of us have barely enough attention span

463.text:
to make it through a two-minute YouTube video
without losing patience and clicking to porn;

467.text:
if we see a website with 500 jokes “by Steven
Wright” we’re just gonna assume they are

473.text: and move on with our lives.

477.text:
Famously never said: “Republicans understand
the importance of bondage between a mother

483.text:
and child,” “The reason we start a war
is to fight a war, win a war, thereby causing

488.text:
Yes, we know. Bush was a moron. And yes, he
did say a lot of incredibly stupid things.

494.text:
However, over a remarkably short period of
time, the legend of Bush’s idiocy has ballooned

499.text:
to cosmically absurd proportions. All you
need to do is take a vaguely political sound

505.text:
bite, mangle the grammar, throw it out on
the Internet as a “Bush-ism” and BAM!

510.text:
Instant credibility. Even if the quote was
blatantly made up in an attempt to mock Bush,

514.text:
it’ll likely be taken as a real quote by
a good chunk of the population

519.text:
There is no real reason for this, since Bush
was more than capable of saying stupid crap

523.text:
on his own. And unlike old-timey people who
may or may not have said stupid things, his

528.text:
blunders are largely documented on video.
No outside help is necessary. But them’s

532.text:
the breaks when you submit one of the worst
Presidencies of all time: people mock you

533.text:
endlessly and just assume you’re even more
brain-dead than you truly are.

535.text:
Famously never said: “I have never let schooling
interfere with my education,” “A lie can

540.text:
make it half way around the world before the
truth has time to put its boots on,” “There

544.text:
are three kinds of lies: lies, damned lies,
and statistics.”

549.text:
To hear most anybody speak of it, Mark Twain
is the funniest person in history, just ahead

554.text:
of Morrissey and the guy who first sprayed
a bunch of shaving cream into a pie plate.

558.text:
As such, he gets all sorts of (sometimes)
witty one-liners credited to him, even though

563.text:
he has books upon books upon books upon books
upon books of ACTUAL witty lines he truly

567.text:
did write. And yet we STILL insist on using
his name for anything that sounds vaguely

572.text: old-timey and might garner a chuckle or two.

575.text:
Probably the silliest example of this is the
“lies, damned lies, and statistics” line

580.text:
he is famous for saying. Except he didn’t;
in fact, his writings make it extremely clear

585.text:
he got the line from former UK Prime Minister
Benjamin Disraeli. However, in a rather fun

590.text:
twist, many people believe Disareli didn’t
say that line EITHER, making the great Mark

595.text:
Twain no better than the hordes of morons
slapping his name on random half-baked jokes

600.text:
in order to make them seem funnier. That would
probably depress him, if he weren’t too
